title: Where did the Christ surname originate? Was that Mary's last name? - Quora

response.answer_text: Christ is not a surname and no it is not Mary’s or Joseph’s name. The term Christ comes from the Greek word Chirstos but was used by early Christian Jews who were looking for the anointed one or Messiah.  "He first findeth his own brother Simon, and saith unto him, We have found the Messias, which is, being interpreted, the Christ" (John 1:41). This came from Daniels prophesy;  Know therefore and understand, that from the going forth of the commandment to restore and to build Jerusalem unto the Messiah the Prince shall beseven weeks, and threescore and two weeks: the street shall be built again, and the wall, even in troublous times. And after threescore and two weeks shall Messiah be cut off, but not for himself: and the people of the prince that shall come shall destroy the city and the sanctuary; and the end thereof shall be with a flood, and unto the end of the war desolations are determined (Daniel Dan 9:25-26). Using the Strong's Exhaustive Concordance Lexicon we can study both words for comparison.   G5547ΧριστόςChristoskhris-tos'From G5548; anointed, that is, the Messiah, an epithet of Jesus: - Christ. G5548χρίωchriōkhree'-oProbably akin to G5530 through the idea of contact; to smear or rub with oil, that is, (by implication) to consecrate to an office or religious service: - anoint.  G3323ΜεσσίαςMessiasmes-see'-asOf Hebrew origin [H4899]; the Messias(that is, Mashiach), or Christ: - Messias.H4899משׁיחmâshı̂yachmaw-shee'-akhFrom H4886; anointed; usually a consecratedperson (as a king, priest, or saint); specifically the Messiah: - anointed, Messiah. H4886משׁחmâshachmaw-shakh'A primitive root; to rubwith oil, that is, to anoint; by implication to consecrate; also to paint: - anoint, paint. The word Messiah grew out of an ancient Hebrew ceremony of anointing or rubbing down certain men with a special cocktail of spices and fragrant oils that, once completed, set the individual apart for certain Jewish positions in their culture, usually to become a prophet, priest or king. There is no record of Jesus being anointed in this manner; however, a certain woman came on one occasion and Mary  came on another occasion and anointed his feet, (Luke 7:38, John 12:3) Jesus was anointed on the day he was Baptized by John the Baptist, "And Jesus, when he was baptized, went up straightway out of the water: and, lo, the heavens were opened unto him, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove, and lighting upon him:" (Mathew 3:16). It was after this happened he went into the desert for 40 days when he returned he began preaching everywhere and when he reached his hometown this is what happened;   And he came to Nazareth, where he had been brought up: and, as his custom was, he went into the synagogue on the sabbath day, and stood up for to read. And there was delivered unto him the book of the prophet Esaias. And when he had opened the book, he found the place where it was written, The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he hath anointed me to preach the gospel to the poor; he hath sent me to heal the brokenhearted, to preach deliverance to the captives, and recovering of sight to the blind, to set at liberty them that are bruised, To preach the acceptable year of the Lord. And he closed the book, and he gave it again to the minister, and sat down. And the eyes of all them that were in the synagogue were fastened on him. And he began to say unto them, This day is this scripture fulfilled in your ears (Luke 4:16-21). Basically he said I am the Christ or Messiah.

As you’d know if you read the rest of the New Testament, most people in that time did not have surnames. Some people had two names (e.g. “Simon Peter”), and some had nicknames based on where they were from (“Saul of Tarsus”, “Mary Magdalene”, etc.) or by who their father was (e.g. “Simon Barjonah”, “James son of Zebedee”) etc. There are still parts of the world where people don’t have surnames but just list the given name of their father and grandfather. So Jesus is variously referred to as “Jesus of Nazareth”, “Jesus son of David” (referring to the tribe and family he was supposed to be from, as a descendant of King David who lived over a thousand years earlier), or in one case “Jesus, son of Mary” which is totally bizarre and without precedent, and makes you wonder what happened to Joseph. In the Bible, a common question or statement is about whether Jesus is “the Christ”. It’s not a surname, at all. It’s a honorific, that is, a title that was given to him by his followers. Here’s just a few examples from the Bible that highlight this: When Jesus came into the region of Caesarea Philippi, He asked His disciples, saying, “Who do men say that I, the Son of Man, am?” So they said, “Some say John the Baptist, some Elijah, and others Jeremiah or one of the prophets.” He said to them, “But who do you say that I am?” Simon Peter answered and said, “You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.” Jesus answered and said to him, “Blessed are you, Simon Bar-Jonah,…..— Matthew 16:13–17 (NKJV) Everyone who believes that Jesus is the Christ is born of God, and everyone who loves the father loves his child as well. — 1 John 5:1 (NIV) In reality, the word “Christ” is the Greek equivalent of the Hebrew word “Messiah”. For example, in the first Bible reference I gave above, if you check it in different translations, many of them say “the Messiah”, rather than “the Christ”. So slowly, after Jesus’ death and the growth of Christianity, the title “Christ” slowly began to be used a bit like a name, but Jesus was never called it like a name. By the way, this is why I hate non-Christians talking about Jesus as “Christ”, like it’s a surname. Only people who venerate him should call him “Christ”, and even then it’s more proper to say “the Christ”. It’s a little bit like Mohandas Gandhi, who often gets called “Mahatma Gandhi” or “the Mahatma”. “Mahatma” was not his name.

No, not Miriam’s surname; (His Mother’s name in Hebrew was Miriam). Actually, the word Christ means Messiah, / Saviour; the Anointed One, chosen by God the Most High. Messiah = Christ = The Anointed One. It is a title, not an actual name but a Title. His earthly name was Yashua or Yahushua in his native Hebrew language, but others saw it fitting to change or translate His name to Jesus, however the letter J does not exist in the Hebrew language, therefore it could not be a legitimate translation, it therefore seem as if Christ’s name was changed to suite a certain nation of people who presented a false image of Yahushua the Christ as being white, by using that of a white man called Cesare Borgia. Christ the Messiah should be called by His original Hebrew name and not by an English name as He was not an English man nor was He white. Why change His given Hebrew name? Also, think of this: why or how is it that all the disciples of Christ were from His nation, they were Israelites, why is it that they all have English names in the Bible? They were not Caucasians / Europeans or from an English or U.K /British origin, neither from the white race as Esau was not their progenitor; they were Jacob’s descendants, dark skinned, what is called black in current times, how did their names become English when they were actual Hebrew Israelites from Jacob? Search the name Cesare Borgia on youtube or just google that name. See what took place with him, a process initiated by his father Pope Alexander 6th.

Christ is not a surname (or last name, as it is commonly known), it means Messiah (or Anointed One). Most people before the First century didn’t have last names (or surnames). Surnames were given based on the city where people were born or lived. For instance, Jesus was born in Jerusalem which is in Judea (or the state of Judah), but he grew up in Nazareth. If you read the Scriptures, everyone knew Him as being from Nazareth. So, if we were to give Jesus a last name, it would’ve been Nazareth because that is where He was from (like Leonardo da Vinci, who was from Vinci-a Metropolitan city of Florence, Italy). Most surnames were based on where a person was born or grew up. In the case of Jesus, there was no such city called Christ. My last name, for instance, means “Son of Sancho” which is an Iberian (Spain/Portugal peninsula) name of Basque (indigenous to and primarily inhabit an area traditionally known as the Basque Country) origin (Santxo, Santzo, Santso, Antzo, Sans). Most Spanish names ending in “ez (son of)” are based on certain towns or cities in Spain. Mary (as Joseph) was from the Tribe of Judah (the state of Judea, also where Judaism [Jews] gets its name).

The original name is Jesus. What is the origin of the name Christ and Christianity? "Christ" is not a name, it is a title. In Christianity, "Christ" (Greek, Χριστός, Christós: "anointed") is interpreted as meaning the savior, or deliverer, of believers from death.¹ It is the Greek translation of the Hebrew word "מָשִׁיחַ, mashiach" (messiah).² ______________ ¹ What Does "Christ" Mean?https://carm.org/what-does-christ-mean Christ (Gr. Christos, translation of Heb. mashiaḥ, “anointed one”) OT Israel anticipated a coming deliverer “anointed” by God to initiate God’s rule of righteousness and peace. Early Christians saw Jesus as fulfilling this hope [as a deliverer from death] and designated him “Christ” (Mark 8: 29; Acts 5: 42; Rom. 5: 6).1 ¹ What does “Christ” actually mean? | Our Rabbi Jesushttp://ourrabbijesus.com/articles/what-does-the-word-christ-actually-mean/ The word “Christ” comes from christos, a Greek word meaning “anointed.” It is the equivalent of the word mashiach, or Messiah, in Hebrew. So, to be the Christ, or Messiah, is to be “the anointed one of God.” To be anointed, literally, is to have sacred oil poured on one’s head, because God has chosen the person for a special task. Priests and kings were anointed, and occasionally prophets. Kings were anointed during their coronation rather than receiving a crown. ² Mashiach: The Messiahhttp://www.jewfaq.org/mashiach.htm Belief in the eventual coming of the mashiach is a basic and fundamental part of traditional Judaism. It is part of Rambam's 13 Principles of Faith,³ the minimum requirements of Jewish belief. In the Shemoneh Esrei prayer, recited three times daily, we pray for all of the elements of the coming of the mashiach: ingathering of the exiles;restoration of the religious courts of justice;an end of wickedness, sin and heresy;reward to the righteous;rebuilding of Jerusalem;restoration of the line of King David;and restoration of Temple service.³ The Thirteen Principles of Jewish Faith - Essentialshttp://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/332555/jewish/Maimonides-13-Principles-of-Faith.htm The great codifier of Torah law and Jewish philosophy, Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon ("Maimonides" also known as "The Rambam"), compiled what he refers to as the Shloshah Asar Ikkarim, the "Thirteen Fundamental Principles" of the Jewish faith, as derived from the Torah. Maimonides refers to these thirteen principles of faith as "the fundamental truths of our religion and its very foundations."

"Christ" is not a surname, it's a title.  It's appended to the Greek form of Yeshua's name as part of a claim that he was the Messiah, which in Greek is Χριστός (Christos).  This in turn is the Greek form of the Hebrew  מָשִׁיחַ (Māšîaḥ) meaning "anointed one".  Ancient Jewish kings were ceremonially anointed with oil as a sign of their status and the Jews believed a new "anointed one" would be sent by God to save them.  The early Jesus sect believed Jesus was this "Anointed" and so referred to Jesus in this way.  So the gospels, which were written in Greek, call him "Ἰησοῦς Χριστός " which in English is "Jesus the Christ" or just "Jesus Christ".  It's a claim, not a name. It's for this reason that only Christians should refer to him as "Jesus Christ".  For we non-Christians, he's just "Jesus" or "Jesus of Nazareth".  Unless you believe he was in some sense "the Christ" it doesn't make sense to refer to him as such. Jesus' historical Aramaic name would have been Yeshua bar Yusef.  His mother would have been Maryām, which was rendered Μαρία (Maria) in the Greek of the gospels which became "Mary" in English translations.

You have your answer for the Christ name not being a surname, but this is the perfect time for a small Surname lesson. Surnames didn't become necessary until the 12th or 13th century. Until people started to leave their family home and move into cities, everyone knew everyone in town. Duplicate names were handled by adding a patrynomic like Jesus son of Joseph or a job title Jesus the Carpenter. If people did emigrate from their town, the location of their home was often added to avoid duplication like Jesus of Nazareth. Interestingly enough, as people first began to get surnames those three choices showed up more than any other. Think of John Johnson, John Baker, or John Weinberger. All names hanging on from those three original ways to distinguish.

"Christ" is not a surname. It's a title. It comes from a Greek word meaning "anointed one". People often have ceremonies of some sort when a person is given an important position or achieves an important milestone. Like we have ceremonies for marriage, "swearing in" of presidents, etc. In those days it was a common part of the ceremony, when someone was appointed to a very high position like king or ambassador, to dribble some vegetable oil on their heads. I don't get the value of this, but then what is the value of most rituals? What's the point of shaking hands or handing a graduate an empty "diploma folder"? Anyway, this was called "anointing". Jesus was called "the anointed one" because he was chosen by God to come to Earth to perform a specific mission. So "Jesus Christ" isn't a first and last name, it's a name and a title. Like calling someone "General Smith".

His name has nothing to do with Mary, Christ means Anointed. He was called Jesus of Nazareth, but that changed on the day He was baptized in the Jordan by John the Baptist. That day John saw The Holy Spirit (of God) came down like a dove and settled in Jesus and said this is My Beloved Son in whom I am well pleased to dwell in (original translation). From that time, Jesus became Christ, that's why He always said the “Father that dwells in Me”. That was how He got the Name Christ. The Jews understood the meaning of this and that's why they accused Jesus Christ of equating Himself WITH GOD. Watch the phrase. No equating to, but with.

The word ‘Christ’ is not a surname. It is an English version of a Greek word (christos) meaning ‘anointed’ and is a translation - into Greek - of the Hebrew word moshiach (which becomes ‘messiah’ in English). Mary would presumably have been named ‘Miriam daughter of whoever her father and mother were’ just like every other Jewish person of the time. And her son Jesus would most likely have been named ‘Yehoshua son of Yosef and Miriam’. She MIGHT have named him ‘Iesus’ or something similar, if she was very fond of the Greek version of Yehoshua. Jews of the late Second Temple period (which includes the entire proposed lifetime of Jesus) did not use surnames or family names.

It’s not a surname. People didn’t have surnames back then. Certainly not Jews, who used patronymics. So during his life Jesus would have been referred to as Jesus Ben Joseph. Yeshoua Ben Yoseph would be the more accurate transliteration. Alternately he could be referred to as Jesus of Nazareth. Nazareth being his home town. But to his followers he would have been Jesus Christ, meaning Jesus the Anointed One. It’s a reference to a specific ritual using sacred oil. But it’s also the Greek translation of Messiah, which is what the Christians believed Jesus to be. So Jesus Christ means Jesus the Messiah.

Obviously I don't agree with Tim O'Neill about the reality of Who Jesus was - he's an atheist and I'm Catholic - but he's right on the money about the word "Christ". "Christ" is the Greek equivalent of the Hebrew "Messiah" (I have no idea how it would be written in the modern transliteration system of Hebrew).  So, the movie got it right: The Passion of the Christ.  Even in the Gospels, Peter says, "You are the Christ, the Son of the living God." It is true that even from Biblical times, people also referred to Jesus simply as "Christ" - but ultimately, it is a title, not a name. Oh, and on a related note, His middle initial is not "H."! :-P

People in those times did not have surnames. They were usually known by their fathers or locations, such as Jesus of Nazareth or James of Zebedee. “Christ” is a title. It is a Greek term for “the anointed.” The Hebrew term is masiah or “messiah.” In ancient Jewish culture, those who were blessed or to become King were anointed with oil. Jesus is referred to as Jesus Christ or Jesus the Messiah because He is “anointed,” or King. It denotes an extremely sacred and special position of the Jewish people.

Christ in Greek ‘anointed’ is a transliteration of His Hebrew title’ Ha Masiach” ‘the Messiah’. Surnames in many cultures have to do with the occupation or livelihood of the father. Joseph (Mary’s Husband) was a carpenter. Yet Joseph was not the biological father of Jesus Christ. Jesus’ Father is the Eternal God, He was born through Divine intervention when the Holy Spirit impregnated Mary with the ‘seed of God’. Jesus’ title or surname is one given as to His role in being anointed of God to save humanity from the wrath of God through His blood being shed to remit our sins.

Jesus name has many origins Letter J. Wasn't used and didn't exist until 15-17 century . The creator bible was completed in 96 AD. The letter j wasn,'t used for about 1400 years after the bible was completed. www. Reocities.com 1. Greek pagan. deity Zesu. 2. Roman Catholic( jesuit) dogmatic leasing . What is the Creator son's name?9 Matt. 1.23 in Heb-I ,Aramaic-A,Gr-EThere are no Hebrew word for one name jesus. Why ?leasing name

Christ is not a surname. It means Messiah. The Messiah (Saviour) was foretold - for hundreds, maybe thousands of years, before Jesus of Nazareth walked on the earth. People were usually given a name and identified as the son of his father. Breaking tradition, the Gospel writers identified Jesus as Son of Mary.

It is not a surname. It is Anglicism from Greek Χριστός, khristos, “the anointed”, which itself is translation from Hebrew מָשִׁיחַ, mosiakh, Messiah. Jesus’s surname would have been ha-Notzri, “The Nazarene”, “bar-Joseph” (son of Joseph) or “bar-Miriam” (son of Mary).

This question does make me chuckle!! as I have never heard it before? Have heard Americans say;”Jesus S.Christ” so perhaps that is where have must have originated?Question answered in full previously. Like the Welsh and others Jesus would have been referred as Yeshua ben Yousef. The Welsh were the same so Jesus would be Jesus ap Joseph. St Peter was Jewish but has a Greek name meaning Rock.or Petrus in Greek. This is due to the Greek influence before the Romans. Jesus referred to him as the Rock.

Christ is not a surname; it is a title. Christ means Anointed One or Messiah… the One sent by God. It would be more correct and more clear if we said “Jesus, the Christ”. In the Bible times, people did not have last names. Communities were smaller and people were known by other descriptions. Jesus’ neighbours may mentioned him as Jesus of Nazareth or Jesus the Carpenter, or Jesus the son of Mary and Joseph.

Tim O'Neill is of course correct to note that Christ was not Jesus' surname but a title (hence Mel Gibson's "The Passion of the Christ"). However, it may be worth adding that Christ is a surname in modern times, a patronymic derived either from Christian or from Christ as a first name. For example, the fern genus Christella is named in honour of Swiss botanist Konrad H. Christ.

“Christ” is a title, not a surname. It derives from Greek word “christos”, popularly symbolized in eastern Roman labarvm (banner) as the accronym “chi-ro” written in Greek alphabets as ‘XP’ :  This is the Greek’s equivalent for the same title in its original language - Hebrew ; “mashiach”, which means “anointed”. Mary’s surname is never mentioned either in the Bible or in the Quran. We can only assume, that her name might followed the usual semites patronymic pattern of those days ; X son/daughter of Z.

The title “CHRIST.” Has its origin in EGYPT 300 years before Jesus came on the seen. The followers of Sarapis, Greco Egyptian god where called Bishops of Christ. And Christian's. For example the followers of Jesus were mistaken for the followers of Sarapis book of Acts chapter 11 vs 26 “ And the Disciples were called Christians first in Antioch.” who called them Christians? The disciples never called themselves Christians.

Christ is the Greek form of Messiah. A messiah is a Moses like figure who is a political, military and religious leader who will lead the Jewish people out of oppression. Paul went to a great deal of trouble to make it mean something else, ie someone who comes to save our sins. A variation of the ancient practice of human sacrifice.

Nopes, that's not mother Mary's surname. Christ has originated from the greek word i.e. christo (kristo) and which in Greek has originated from sanskrit word in vedas means (akarshit) which means all attractive and which in turn has originated from GOD name Krsna. In many terms you will also find the teachings of both are perfectly identical. Couple of time you will also find that Jesus never claim that he's GOD but son of GOD who's all attractive.

“Christ” is not a surname. It is a title. It means “Messiah” or “anointed one.” Surnames did not become a thing until thousands of years later, and people were identified by their given name and then “son of. . .” or simply “of…” this is why Jesus is also known as “Jesus of Nazareth.”

There are eighteen answers, I have upvoted many answers. I bring the attention to compare these resemblances. Lord Krishna is not God but descendant of God. He was born in a Shepherd family. He was born in a prison. He protected the suffering people. Jesus Christ is not God but descendant of God. He was called a Shepherd. He born in a cattle shed. He anointed the sufferings and protected them. There are many more similarities but now I can't recollect them, I will update later.

They changed it at Ellis Island. Originally it was Gonzalez…Jesus Gonzalez…. Maria and Jose Gonzalez were his parents… Mateo, Marco, Lucas, and Juan…then of course, Pablo, Pedro Jaime…the professor and Mary Ann. And the 3 Vatos from the east side, plus Maria Magdalena, the puta…

Today Christ is a surname (not very common) in Germany. It comes from the given name Christian (from Greek Christianos “Follower of Christ”). Greek Christos is a translation of Hebrew Messias. The name is also known for a chain of jewelry stores, founded 1863 by clockmaker Wilhelm Alexander Christ.

You will do better to check surnames sites, or just Google your question. I went through a couple dozen, and got tired of people ranting the same non answer. If you do find an answer somewhere, you should put it here as a reply. It will load at top, and keep people from this long winded thread going nowhere in a snail's pace.
It is not a surname. “Christ” comes from the Greek word, “Christos,” meaning “anointed one.” From the Hebrew, it is “Messiah,” or, “Meshiach.” Same meaning.
In Christianity, Christ [Notes 1] (Greek: Χριστός, Christós, meaning "the anointed one") is a title for the saviour and redeemer who would bring salvation to the whole House of Israel.
Middle English Crist, from Old English, from Latin Christus,from Greek Christos, literally, anointed, from chrieinFirst Known Use: before 12th century
“Christ” isn't the surname of Jesus. Christ means Anointed and Messiah. It's from the Greek word “Christos”. And name “Jesus” is from the Hebrew word “Yeshua”.

In Albanian language JESUS means JE MSUS meaning a TEACHER, and JESUS CHRIST means CROSS TEACHER, though considering from Albanian language CHRIST it is a word describing a CROSS SIGN, meaning of A CRUCIFIED TEACHER, or Teacher hanged on a cross. If there is a better explanation rather than Albanian language please comment!!!
christ is short for christos….meaning annointed
